clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Upright Patient Positioning on Intubation Success
clinical_study.official_title: Prospective Observational Study of the Effect of Upright Patient Positioning on Intubation Success Rates at Two Academic Emergency Departments

brief_summary.textblock: Endotracheal intubation is most commonly taught and performed with the patient supine. Recent literature suggests that elevating the patient's head to a more upright position may decrease peri-intubation complications. However, there is little data on success rates of upright intubation in the emergency department. The goal of this study was to measure the association of head positioning with intubation success rates among emergency medicine residents.

detailed_description.textblock: Endotracheal intubation is most commonly taught and performed with the patient supine. Recent literature suggests that elevating the patient's head to a more upright position may decrease peri-intubation complications. However, there is little data on success rates of upright intubation in the emergency department. The goal of this study was to measure the association of head positioning with intubation success rates among emergency medicine residents. Study design was a prospective observational study. Residents performing intubation recorded the angle of the head of the bed, and the number of attempts required for successful intubation was recorded by faculty and respiratory therapists. The primary outcome of first past success was calculated with respect to three groups: 0-10 degrees (supine), 11-44 degrees (inclined), and â‰¥45 degrees (upright); first past success was also analyzed in 5 degree angle increments.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately at the time of the procedure
primary_outcome.description: An attempt was defined as anytime the laryngoscope blade was placed in the patient's mouth. At the beginning of the study residents, faculty, and RTs were educated on this definition.

secondary_outcome.measure: overall success rate of orotracheal intubation overall success rate of orotracheal intubation overall success rate of intubation
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately at the time of the procedure
Immediately at the time of the procedure
Immediately at the time of the procedure
secondary_outcome.description: endotracheal tube determined to be positioned in esophagus rather

secondary_outcome.measure: cardiac arrest within 30 minutes of the intubation attempt
secondary_outcome.time_frame: cardiac arrest within 30 minutes of intubation

secondary_outcome.measure: decrease in oxygen saturation during the procedure
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately at the time of the procedure
Immediately at the time of the procedure
secondary_outcome.description: Cormack-Lehane view is a scale that is used to describe the amount of vocal cords visualized during the procedure
Percent of glottis opening refers to the percentage of vocal cords and surrounding anatomy which can be seen during the procedure
survey completed following the procedure by provider regarding satisfaction

secondary_outcome.time_frame: While in the emergency department (1 hour up to 1 day)

secondary_outcome.description: any cause of death within 5 days after intubation
new pneumonia developed within 5 days following an intubation. Not present on admission.

arm_group.description: Intubations performed with patient positioned 0-10 degrees. Patient supine.
Intubations performed with 11-44 degrees of elevation.
intubations performed with patient elevated to 45 degrees or greater

intervention.description: Upright Intubation procedure performed with patient elevated above the supine position. Defined as upright greater to or equal to 45 degrees or inclined 10-44 degrees

study_pop.textblock: Intubation events that were eligible for enrollment included adult medical intubations performed at participating hospitals in which the intubating resident and supervising faculty both consented to study participation.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adult medical intubations in which the intubating resident and supervising faculty both consented to study participation.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pediatric patients
- Obstetric patients
- Trauma patients
